texts.shortText: Oval, but almost always deformed and with a distinctly irregular margin. Hinge displaces well towards anterior end. Shell valves dirty-white or grey and sculptured with course radiating ridges and finer concentric growth lines. Interior often with a reddish-brown posterior patch. Best identified by its unusual habit of excavating shallow, rounded burrows onto soft sandstone and limestone.

Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern KwaZulu-Natal.

Excavates shallow, rounded burrows into soft limestone or sandstone, smaller individuals also sometimes found burrowing into shells of large gastropods. Burrows bored by abrading away the rock with the rough sculpturing on anterior surfaces of the shells, as these are rocked against one another. Opening to the burrow closed with a plug of sand and mucus, the long siphons reaching though this plug into the water above. Inconspicuous and mostly found dead, but still in their burrows, after host rocks are washed ashore in storms. Can be abundant and rocks densely pitted with the characteristic burrows are common.

Specimens from the east coast are more regular in shape, darker in colour and more strongly sculptured than those from the west coast and may prove to represent another undescribed species.

As with most bivalves filter-feed by sucking water in through an inhalant siphon, filtering out fine food particles by passing the water though the enlarged sieve-like gills and then ejecting waste water though a exhalent siphon.
Broadcast spawners, ejecting sperm and eggs into the water column, where they merge to form pelagic larvae to drift in the plankton and settle in other suitable sites.

Unlikely to be confused with other species due to the unusual rock-boring habits and irregular shell shape. Burrows are sometimes confused with those created by piddocks (Pholas dactylus), but piddock burrows are much deeper, linear and tapering, while those of Petricola are shallow and cup shaped.
Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 201).
